question: I beg your pardon, but aren't you Guy Haines. Sure! I saw you blast Faraday right off the court in South Orange last season. What a backhand! Made the semi-finals, didn't you? I certainly admire people who do things. I'm Bruno Anthony. Bruno. See Guy looks up. Bruno indicates his gold tie pin which bears his name in cut- out letters. Guy looks at it with the faintest expression of disdain. I suppose you think it's corny. But my mother gave it to me so of course I wear it to please her.
answer: How do you do.

question: I don't usually talk so much. Go Ahead and read.
answer: Thanks. Guy tries to read but is uneasily aware of Bruno's open appraisal.

question: It must be pretty exciting to be so important.
answer: A tennis player isn't so important.

question: People who do things are important. I never seem to do anything. I suppose you're going to Southampton -- for the doubles.
answer: You are a tennis fan.

question: Wish I could see you play. But I've got to be back in Washington tomorrow. I live in Arlington, you know. Cigarette?
answer: Not now, thanks. I don't smoke much.

question: I smoke too much. Thanks. Elegant.
answer: Yes?

question: Anne Burton. Sometimes I turn the sport page and look at the society news. And the pictures. She's very beautiful, Senator Burton's daughter.
answer: You're quite a reader, Mr. Anthony.

question: Yes, I am. Ask me anything, from today's stock reports to Li'l Abner, and I got the answer. Even news about people I don't know. Like who'd like to marry whom when his wife gets her divorce.
answer: Perhaps you read too much.

question: There I go again. Too friendly. I meet someone I' like and open my yap too wide. I'm sorry... At the appeal on Bruno's face, Guy slowly relents.
answer: That's all right. Forget it. I guess I'm pretty jumpy.

question: There's a new cure for that. Scotch and plain water. A pair. Double. Only kind of doubles I play.
answer: You'll have to drink both of them.

question: And I can do it. When's the wedding?
answer: What?

question: The wedding. You and Anne Burton. It was in the papers.
answer: It shouldn't have been. Unless they've legalized bigamy overnight.

question: I have a theory about that. I'd like to tell you about it some time. But right now I suppose divorce Is still the simplest operation.
answer: I guess I will.

question: This is wonderful -- having your company all the way to New York.
answer: As a matter of fact, I'm not going direct. I'm stopping off. At Metcalf.

question: Metcalf? What would anybody want to go there for?
answer: It's my home town.

question: Oh, I get it! A little talk with your wife to about the divorce! I suppose she was the girl next door. Held her hand in high school and before you knew it -- hooked! Am I right?
answer: Close enough.

question: Well, here's luck, Guy. Drink up -- then we'll have some lunch sent to my compartment.
answer: Thanks very much. But I think I'll go to the dining car. Do you know if there are any vacant seats in the dining car now?

question: See? You'll have to lunch with me. Say, waiter, bring me some lamb chops and French fries and chocolate ice cream, Compartment D, Car 121. What'll you have, Guy?
answer: Thanks just the same, but I really don't think --

question: Oh, go on and order.
answer: Well, I'll Just have a hamburger and a cup of coffee.

question: To the next Mrs. Haines. Sure, I went to college. Three of them. Every time they kicked me out my father threw me back in. He finally gave up. He thinks I'm awfully small fry, not worth the bait. You my friend, Guy?
answer: Sure. I'm your friend, Bruno.

question: No, you're not, nobody thinks I'm anything special. Only my mother. My father hates me.
answer: You must be imagining things.

question: And I hate him. He thinks I ought to catch the eight-five bus every morning, punch a timeclock and work my way up selling paint or something. Him -- with all his money!
answer: Well, what do you want to do?

question: You mean before or after I kill him?
answer: Before, of course.

question: I want to do everything. I got a theory you're supposed to do everything before you die. Have you ever driven a car, blindfolded, at a hundred and fifty miles an hour?
answer: Not lately.

question: I did. I flew in a jet plans too. Zzzzzzzp! Man, that's a thrill! Almost blow the sawdust out of my head. I'm going to make a reservation on the first rocket to the moon...
answer: What are you trying prove?

question: I'm not like you, Guy. You're lucky. You're smart. Marrying the boss's daughter is a nice short cut to a career, isn't it?
answer: Marrying the senator's daughter has nothing to do with it. Can't a fellow look past a tennis not without being a goldbricker?

question: Take it easy, boy. I'm your friend, remember? I'd do anything for you.
answer: Sure, Bruno, sure. We'll be pulling in soon. I've got to change trains.

question: What'd you say her name was -- your wife's?
answer: Miriam.

question: That's it. Miriam Joyce Haines. Played around a lot, I suppose?
answer: Let's not talk about it any more.

question: Maybe she'll make more trouble for you.
answer: I don't think so.

question: You mean you got enough on her to get your divorce no matter what?
answer: Let's change subject, Bruno, can't we?

question: Okay, Guy. Want me to tell you one of my ideas for murdering my father?
answer: You've been reading too many of these.

question: You want to hear about the busted light socket in the bathroom, or the carbon monoxide in the garage?
answer: No. I may be old fashioned, but I thought murder was against the law.

question: But not against the law of nature. My theory is that everybody is a potential murderer. Didn't you ever want to kill somebody? Say one of those useless fellows Miriam was running around with?
answer: You can't go around killing people just because you think they're useless.

question: Oh, what's a life or two? Some people are bitter off dead, Guy. Take your -- wife and my father, for instance. It reminds me of a wonderful idea had once. I used to put myself to sleep at night -- figuring it out. Now, let's say you want to get rid of your wife.
answer: Why?

question: Let's say she refuses to give you a divorce -- Let's say. You'd be afraid to kill her because you'd get caught. And what would trip you up? Motive. Now here's the plan...
answer: I'm afraid I haven't time to listen.

question: It's so simple, too. A couple of fellows meet accidentally, like you and me. No connection between them at all. Never saw each other before. Each of them has somebody he'd like to get rid of, but he can't murder the person he wants to get rid of. He'll get caught. So they swap murders.
answer: Swap murders?

question: Each fellow does the other fellow's murder. Then there is nothing to connect them. The one who had the motive isn't there. Each fellow murders a total stranger. Like you do my murder and I do yours.
answer: We're coming into my station.

question: For example, your wife, my father. Criss-cross.
answer: What?

question: We do talk the same language -- don't we, Guy?
answer: Sure, we talk the same language. Thanks for the lunch.

question: I'm glad you enjoyed it. I thought the lamb chops were a little overdone myself.
answer: Nice meeting you, Bruno.

question: You think my theory is okay, Guy? You like it?
answer: Sure, sure, Bruno. They're all okay.

question: Criss-cross.
answer: Hi, Bill. Then park these in a lucky spot for a few hours, will you?

question: Hi, Bill. Then park these in a lucky spot for a few hours, will you?
answer: Even change. Thank you, Madam. Well -- hello, Guy.

question: You're looking well, Miriam.
answer: So are you. You've got a nice tan, playing tennis with all your rich friends.

question: What time do we meet your lawyer?
answer: What's your hurry?

question: My hurry? That's funny, coming from you! You're the one who's in a hurry, aren't you?
answer: When you wouldn't give me the divorce right away, I sort of hoped it was because you were a little bit jealous.

question: I got over being jealous, a long time ago Miriam. Miriam's eyes slide toward the other girl clerk who has moved closer, within listening range.
answer: Let's talk in there. Now this is cosier. Sort of like old times, isn't it, Guy?

question: Oh, skip it, Miriam. It's pretty late to start flirting with a discarded husband. Especially when you're going to have another man's baby.
answer: Do you know, I think you're handsomer than ever?

question: Let's see your lawyer and get this over with.
answer: Did you bring the money, Guy? Lawyers are expensive.

question: Here it is.
answer: If I'd known what all that tennis nonsense of yours was going to lead to, I wouldn't have run out on you.

question: What are you trying to say, Miriam? Come out with it.
answer: I'm not getting a divorce.

question: Why, you little doublecrosser. I didn't want this divorce, you did. That's what you've been harping about for the past year.
answer: It's a woman's privilege to change her mind... Now I can shop for some pretty clothes. I wouldn't want you to be ashamed of me in Washington when we go to all those dinners and swanky parties.

question: And what do you mean by that?
answer: Don't look so mad, Guy. You always smile when your picture is being taken for the papers. Especially when you have Anne Burton hanging on your arm.

question: Let's not talk about Anne Burton.
answer: So, it's really serious between you two? Well, you can throw your dreams about her into the ashcan. Guy, I'm coming to Washington.

question: What for?
answer: To have my baby and be with you.

question: Why me? It's not my baby.
answer: But people don't know that, Guy, do they? It would make a pretty story, wouldn't it -- the senator's daughter involved with a married man who's about to become a father.

question: You black conniving little liar!
answer: Keep your voice down.

question: What happened? Did he run out on you?
answer: No man runs out on me. Not even you.

question: You're a liar and a cheat, Miriam. You've wanted to get rid of me long enough and now I'll go you one better -- I never want to see or hear of you again.
answer: I could be very pathetic as the deserted little mother in a courtroom, Guy. Think it over. Who would believe you?

question: ...That's what should happen to people like you. And if I... Sorry. I'm leaving.
answer: You heard what I said, Guy Haines. You can't throw me away like an old shoe. I'm coming to Washington to have my baby. Tell that to the senate!

question: Since you insisted on a manicure, dear, I do wish you'd keep your hands quiet. You're so restless lately.
answer: I like them to look just right.

question: Did I file them too short?
answer: No, Ma. They look fine. Thanks.

question: Then what's the matter?
answer: I'm all right, Ma. Don't worry about me.

question: You look so Pale, dear. Are you out of vitamins?
answer: I bought a bottle of them yesterday. A whole fifth.

question: But you have that 'look'. I can always tell. You haven't got into any more mischief, Bruno? I do hope you've forgotten about that silly little plan of yours?
answer: Which one?

question: About blowing up the White House?
answer: I was only kidding, Ma. Besides, what would the president say?

question: You're a naughty boy, Bruno. But you can always make me laugh. Now get shaved, dear, before your father gets home.
answer: I'm sick and tired of bowing and scraping to the king.

question: Now, now, Let's not lose control. Come see my painting, dear -- I do wish you'd take up painting. It's such a soothing pastime.
answer: You're wonderful, Ma! It's the old boy, all right. That's father!

question: It is? I was trying to paint Saint Francis. How nice that you're early, Charles. I'll tell cook....
answer: Sorry father. Long distance. Hello... Guy? Bruno, Bruno Anthony. I just wanted to ask how you made out with Miriam.

question: There was a man, now please take note. There was a man who had a goat. He loved that goat, Indeed he did. He loved that goat, just like a kid. What is your opinion?
answer: You'll never make the Metropolitan.

question: Name's Collins. On sabbatical - Delaware Tech. Glad to meet you. I jus' gave a speech in New York. On integration. In the differential calculus a function is given and its differential is obtained. Understand?
answer: Sure, I understand.

question: I was very careful. Even when I dropped your lighter there, I went right back to it up. If It'd been found, it would have ruined our whole scheme, wouldn't it?
answer: Are you trying to tell me you've -- Why, you maniac!

question: But, Guy, you wanted it! We planned it on the train together, remember? Where are you going?
answer: Where do you think I'm going? I'm going to call the police, of course.

question: But you can't, Guy. We'd both be arrested for murder.
answer: We'd both be arrested for murder?

question: You're is much in it as I am. We planned it together. Criss-cross. I do your murder --
answer: You crazy fool! You think you can get away with that?

question: Oh, come now, Guy. Why should I go to Metcalf and kill a total stranger, unless it was part of the plan and you were in on it? You're the one that benefits, Guy. You're a free man. I didn't even know the girl.
answer: Let me go, Bruno. I had nothing to do with this and the police will believe me.

question: Wait a minute, Guy. To have to talk. We have to arrange things.
answer: Get away before I give you what you gave Miriam.

question: You're not yourself, Guy. You're tired. When you think things over, you'll see I'm right. Tomorrow --
answer: I don't know you. I never saw you before. I never want to see you again.

question: But we have to --
answer: Yes? Yes, Anne. I'm sorry, darling. I just got in. Of course I'm all right. But you sound upset. Is anything wrong? All right. I'll come over. Right away. Anne darling, you're trembling.

question: It happened on an island in an amusement park. It was sort of a lovers lane, I believe. A rather sordid atmosphere.
answer: Miriam went there with two boys. They were the ones who found her. So they're not suspects. But you probably will be.

question: Young lady, we can't overlook the fact that murder is at our doorsteps. But I forbid you to drag it into the living room!
answer: Let's not fool ourselves. The police will say Guy wanted Miriam out of the way so he could marry Anne. In a crime of this sort the police first go after the husband, and Guy had every motive.

question: Yes, I spoke to someone.
answer: Anyone you know?

question: No. His name was Collins. He is a professor.
answer: Harvard.

question: Profit by my experience, Guy. Never lose any sleep over accusations. Unless they can be proved, of course. We'll help all we can. Dreadful business, dreadful. That poor unfortunate girl.
answer: She was a tramp.

question: She was a human being. let me remind you that even the most unworthy of us has the right to life and the pursuit of happiness.
answer: From what I hear, she pursued it in all directions.

question: Of course, of course. Back to bed, Barbara.
answer: Well, you two. Nothing stands in your way now. You can be married right away. Think of it -- you're free!

question: One doesn't always have to say what one thinks!
answer: Father, I'm not a politician.

question: Unfortunately, I remember very little about the journey from New York...You see, there had been a little celebration --
answer: But we were sitting opposite each other in the observation car! You were singing a song about a goat --

question: A goat?
answer: And calculus. You were going over a speech you'd made.

question: I'll have him called off immediately of course.
answer: I'm afraid where I go, Hennessy goes. Even to the Senate.

question: Is he likely to -- picket my office?
answer: Very likely.

question: I would suggest, Guy, for your own peace of mind, of course, that you work here at the house for a few days. It would be less embarrassing for you.
answer: Then what about practicing? Perhaps I'd better forget Forest Hills?

question: Must be some mistake. It wasn't for me. Well, I suppose I was pretty lucky to be seeded fifth, really.
answer: I've never seen the Forest Hillss tournament before. I'm looking forward to it.

question: Do you mean we'll be going there together, Hennessy?
answer: Oh, don't worry. This thing will be cleared up by that time. Ever thought of turning professional, Guy?

question: I won't have to do that. When I'm through with tennis. I'll be going into politics, I hope.
answer: Politics! It's a good thing for you I don't report that to the chief. -- He'd put ten men on your trail. He says --

question: Let's take this cab. It's getting late. Pentagon Building, please.
answer: Oh, no, not there! I always get lost.

question: Well, we'd better be getting back.
answer: We've actually been alone for an hour. Seems almost indecent. You like?

question: I like.
answer: I was beginning to feel like a goldfish.

question: So was I. When we build our house, darling, we won't even have glass windows. No doorbells, no newspapers, no telephone --
answer: No Hennessy.

question: How long can it go on?
answer: I don't know. I suppose until they find out who did it.

question: We'll be happier then, won't we?
answer: I suppose so.

question: Will you stop pestering me!
answer: But Guy, you haven't called me. My father's leaving for Florida the end of this week --

question: You crazy fool! There's a detective outside. He'll see us together!
answer: Oh, they can't have anything on you. Isn't that Anne Burton? Slight improvement over Miriam -- eh, Guy?

question: Hiya, Hennessy. Won't keep you out late tonight. With Forest Hills coming up tomorrow, I've got to get some sleep.
answer: That's too bad. Hammond takes over in a couple of hours. I'd like to see him earn his salary.

question: Doesn't that bloodhound over relax? He sticks so close he's beginning to grow on me -- like a fungus.
answer: He thinks you're a very suspicious character. He doesn't trust anybody! Not even himself.

question: Come on. Don't forget your sleeping bag.
answer: Yeah, If I have to wait too long on the sidewalk my feet get cold. And if I sit too long on those stone steps, my --

question: Don't worry. Since you told Barbara Burton about the icebox, you're her favorite charity. She'll send the butler out with something to defrost you.
answer: Cute kid.

question: But tell me, Judge, after you've sentenced a man to the chair, isn't it difficult to go and eat your dinner after that? Quite impersonal, isn't it, sir? So few murderers are caught.
answer: Well, Mr. Antony, you seem very interested in the subject of murder.

question: No more than anyone else. No more than you, for instance.
answer: Me? I'm not interested in murder.

question: Oh, come now, everyone's interested in that. Everyone would like to put someone out of the way. Now surely, Madame, you're not going to tell me that there hasn't been a time when you wanted to dispose of someone. Your husband, for instance.
answer: Good heavens, no!

question: Ah ah! Are you sure? Do you mean to tell me there wasn't a tiny moment - when you'd been made really angry? And what did you say?
answer: Well...

question: There you are, you see! There you are! All right, now you're going -- to do a murder. How are you going to do it? This is the fascinating part -- how are you going to do it...I didn't get your name?
answer: Mrs. Cunningham.

question: Mrs. Cunningham, how are you going to do it?
answer: Well, I suppose I'll have to get a gun from somewhere.

question: Tssk, tssk. Oh no, Mrs. Cunningham. Bang, bang, all over the place. Blood everywhere? Ah! That's better, that's better. Mrs.....? That's better, Mrs. Anderson. But Mrs. Cunningham is in a dreadful hurry. Poison could take...let's see...ten to twelve weeks, if poor Mr. Cunningham is to die from natural causes.
answer: I have a wonderful Idea! I can take him out in the car and when I get to a lonely spot, knock him on the head with a hammer, pour gasoline over him and over the car and start the whole thing ablaze.

question: And then have to walk all that way home? No, I have the best way, and the best tools. Simple, silent, and quick. The silent part being the most important. Let me show you what I mean. You don't mind if I borrow your neck for a moment do you?
answer: Well, it's not for long.

question: What happened? I was on a merry-go- round somewhere. It made me dizzy.
answer: You're a mad, crazy maniac, and you ought to be locked-up! Now will you get out of here and let me alone?

question: But, Guy -- You shouldn't have done that, Guy.
answer: Come on -- pull yourself together. Do your tie up. Here -- let me. Have you got a car here?

question: You didn't meet him for the first time the other day, did you, Guy?
answer: You mean when you introduced us at the club?

question: Yes. Did you notice how he stared at Barbara that day?
answer: Well, I didn't -- particularly --

question: He stared at her again tonight -- while his hands were around Mrs. Cunningham's throat. What did Miriam look like, Guy.
answer: Well, why do you ask me? You've seen her pictures in the paper.

question: Go on, I want you to tell me.
answer: Well, she was dark, not too tall, rather pretty --

question: What else?
answer: What else is there?

question: She wore glasses, didn't she?
answer: Yes.

question: She looked a lot like Barbara, didn't she? How did you get him to do it, Guy.
answer: I get him to do it?

question: He killed Miriam, didn't he? Tell me, Guy!
answer: Yes. He's a maniac. I met him on the train going to Metcalf. He had a crazy scheme about exchanging murders. I do his murder and he do mine.

question: What do you mean -- your murder, Guy?
answer: Well, he'd read about me in the paper. He knew about Miriam -- and about you. He suggested that if he got rid of Miriam for me, I should kill his father.

question: You must have realized he was talking a lot of nonsense!
answer: Of course! I didn't give it another thought. And now a lunatic wants me to kill his father.

question: It's too fantastic!
answer: Yes, isn't it?

question: You mean you've known about Miriam all this time?
answer: Since the first night. He gave me her glasses.

question: Why didn't you call the police?
answer: And have them say what you did -- "Mr. Haines, how did you get him to do it?" And Bruno would say we'd planed it together.

question: Oh, Guy -- what can we do?
answer: I don't know, Anne...I don't know.

question: Guy, hadn't we better go inside? Your friend Hennessy's watching us.
answer: You see, Anne, that's why I didn't want you to know anything about this. I wanted to protect all of you -- your father, Barbara. And now that you know, you're acting guilty, too.

question: Oh, if we could only talk to father or someone about it.
answer: No, that's no good, Anne. I mustn't drag anyone else into this mess. Come on. Let's go in.

question: My father isn't home tonight, Mr. Haines. I was about to tell you that over the phone. But you came to such a sudden decision. I wondered why.
answer: Since you sent me a key to your house, I decided to use it -- to make a little social call on your father. I thought he'd be Interested to know he his a lunatic son.

question: Then a I correct, Mr. Haines, in assuming that you have no intention of going ahead with our arrangement?
answer: No intention whatsoever. I never had.

question: I see. You won't have any further use for the key, then, Mr. Haines. Thank you very such.
answer: Or this. Look, Bruno. You're terribly sick. I don't know whether it's possible for you to realize it or not. I don't know much about these things, Bruno. But why don't you go someplace where you can get some treatment? Not only for your own sake, Bruno, but you can't go on causing more and more destruction to anyone you happen to meet.

question: He came back at three twenty-five. I didn't even know he'd given me the slip until his 'phone kept ringing for about half an hour. Nobody sleeps that sound. So I got the janitor to let me in. No Haines.
answer: Wonder where he went?

question: We'll probably hear of another dame murdered.
answer: Shut up. I'd better contact Metcalf. I should think this calls for more questioning of Mr. Haines.

question: Questioning? Nuts! Let's take him in.
answer: My dear Mr. Hamond, how many times do I have to tell you that we have nothing conclusive on Haines? There's no evidence that he was ever at the scene of the crime. Can't you get that into your thick head? Now stay put till I get back.

question: Oh, now, Miss Burton, really! I know Bruno's been in some very awkward scrapes, but nothing so ridiculous as a murder.
answer: But, Mrs. Antony, you've got to make him do something about this. Don't you see that just one word from him would extricate Guy from this dreadful situation?

question: Oh, but Miss Burton, I'm sure this thing must be some practical joke. You know, Bruno sometimes goes too far. Of course I shouldn't be saying this to an outsider, but sometimes he's terribly irresponsible and gets into all kinds of escapades.
answer: But don't you understand, Mrs. Antony -- your son is responsible for a woman's death.

question: Did Bruno tell you this?
answer: Of course not, Mrs. Antony.

question: ...And he said that if the police found your lighter there, that's all they'd need -- something to prove you were at the scene of the murder.
answer: That big lie about my wanting him to get it back means he's going to put my lighter on that island!

question: Guy, you'll have to get there before he does. You won't have time to play, You'd better tell them.
answer: Darling, if that loudspeaker announces that I'm not going to play, Hennessy bound to be suspicious He'd keep me from ever getting near Metcalf.

question: Then I'll go.
answer: No, darling. You stay right here and help me give Hennessy the slip after the match.

question: But, Guy, that'll be too late!
answer: Didn't Bruno say that I wanted him together there one night after dark?

question: Yes.
answer: Well, that's what's in his mind now. He's not going to expose himself in broad daylight, If I can finish off this match in three sets, I'll still get there in time. Okay, Tim. Be right with you.

question: We'll know more about that by the end of the week... Be right there. I was afraid you wouldn't get here. Wish me luck, darling.
answer: Guy, listen to me, If I sound all mixed up I can't help it. I -- I'm scared.

question: What about?
answer: That's just it. I don't know. It's Bruno. I talked to him, Guy -- He acted peculiar -- as if he could put the murder right in your lap, and not involve himself at all.

question: He'd drag himself into it, -- and Bruno loves Bruno. I'm all right so long as he thinks I have an alibi for that night. He knows? Then he'll think of something. He said he would.
answer: Guy, has he anything that the police could trace to you -- Any little thing.

question: My cigarette lighter. He said once he could have left it on the islands as evidence But he wouldn't do that. Not in broad day light.
answer: But he's going somewhere, Guy. He told his mother --

question: Metcalf -- did he say Metcalf?
answer: No, -- I don't think so. Oh, why can't I remember -- he said such crazy things!

question: Try to think, Anne!
answer: Something about the moon -- he said he had an appointment with the moon.

question: That's no help. But I can't take any chances. I've got to get that lighter -- somehow. I'll have to default.
answer: And have Hennessy and that other one right at your heels?

question: He has my cigarette lighter and wanted to plant it there on the island to pin the whole thing on me. Let me talk to him. Let me show you. Where is he? Can't you get that stuff off him?
answer: Hello, Guy. Who's that?

question: This is Mr. Turley, Chief of Police.
answer: So they got you at last, eh, Guy?

question: Can you talk a little? Can you tell the chief you have my lighter?
answer: I haven't got it. It's still on the island where you left it.
